Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Hydrological tipping points and desertification of semi-arid woodlands
Award.AbstractNarration:
Forest mortality caused by drought has recently increased and is now of global concern. This project is designed to improve the ability of ecologists to predict the impact of significant tree die-off in semi-arid, forested ecosystems. The study focuses on piñon-juniper woodlands. In the Southwest U.S., where they occur, higher temperatures and decreased precipitation have increased drought severity, reducing tree health, and triggering widespread tree death across the region. This research is motivated by previous findings showing that piñon pine mortality unexpectedly leads to woodlands becoming hotter and drier, potentially altering the environmental conditions that control future plant growth and ecosystem recovery. These surprising results challenge the expectation that tree mortality would lead to increased soil water availability. This work will contribute key data on the specific roles of woody plants in regulating water availability in water-limited, semi-arid ecosystems following mortality of large numbers of trees. The modeling will clarify the extent to which specific forests are vulnerable to drought and changing climate, and will help to identify key environmental factors that increase vulnerability. One postdoctoral researcher, two graduate students, and several undergraduate researchers will receive training and support at two Hispanic-American Serving Institutions. This study will inform regional natural resource managers of climate effects and develop activities for students from Albuquerque-area and San Marcos, TX schools through STEM focused K-12 education programs at both institutions.

The project will test the overarching hypothesis that tree density in semi-arid biomes may represent a tipping point, such that a decrease in tree density due to drought-induced mortality can trigger a potentially irreversible drying of the system, and transition to a new ecosystem state. The project will address: 1) specific mechanisms that explain why plant-available soil moisture and remaining juniper and small piñon pine tree function decreases following piñon mortality (decrease of hydraulic redistribution, altered energy balance, or reduced infiltration due to hydrophobic litter inputs); and which process, if any, is dominant; 2) if there are specific tree density thresholds or species-specific community compositions that facilitate aridification following tree mortality; 3) if there are soil structure and/or precipitation regimes in semi-arid woodlands that facilitate aridification following tree mortality and 4) what is the likelihood that these disturbed woodlands will return to their previous state or progress to a new ecosystem state. The experimental design is centered on nine large plots, three with no disturbance that will act as controls, three in which all piñon pines are girdled, and three in which all juniper are girdled, which will allow the research team to examine species-specific roles of piñon and juniper in regulating the hydrology of these woodlands. Measurements include the response of hydraulic redistribution and sapflow in the remaining species, soil moisture profiles, and surface energy balance components, which will be used to constrain a land surface model, the Community Land Model (CLM 4.5), modified to include hydraulic redistribution. The proposed work will greatly enhance the ability to predict how and why coniferous mortality in semi-arid biomes may trigger aridification, advance our understanding of the links between tree mortality and hydrology in semi-arid systems, and quantify the role of hydraulic distribution at the ecosystem scale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

Forests and woodlands provide critical ecosystem services from local to global scales, but they are increasingly threatened by drought-induced tree mortality. Many scientific investigations to date have focused on where, when and how die-off events occur. This project asked what happens in the aftermath of tree mortality: how are ecosystem processes impacted by the sudden loss of overstory trees and how does this affect forest recoverability?  The study was conducted in a piñon-juniper (PJ) woodland, the most common forest type in the Southwestern United States covering 40 million hectares from Mexico to Idaho. These woodlands have been especially hard hit by recurrent drought events over the past 20 years and previous studies suggested that tree mortality leads to woodlands becoming hotter and drier. Potentially, this would make it harder, if not impossible, for these communities to fully recover.

This project examined the impact of tree mortality on ecosystem processes in a rigorously designed, manipulative field experiment, in which either piñon (Pinus edulis) or juniper (Juniperus monosperma) trees were killed by girdling and ecosystem impacts were evaluated comprehensively by comparison with an intact woodland control. It was learned that tree mortality, in addition to amplifying the negative effects of drought conditions, can also amplify the positive effects of normal to wet climate conditions. The reduction in live tree density increased soil water and nutrient availability, which in turn enhanced the water status, photosynthesis, growth and survival of juniper and piñon seedlings and saplings (juveniles) in the understory. Piñon juveniles benefited more from the death of piñon trees and juniper juveniles benefited equally from the death of either tree species. These effects were mitigated by the spatial distribution of juveniles, which were more numerous under tree clusters. Though piñon juvenile mortality was overall higher than juniper juvenile mortality, as observed in other studies, faster growth during wet years would allow piñon juveniles to reach a safe size and mature sooner, counteracting the inevitable decline in seed production after a piñon die-off. The study generated the novel insight that climate conditions immediately following a drought-induced tree mortality can have a disproportionate effect on the subsequent path of woodland recovery.  

Broader Impact  

Results were shared with a private land consortium, the Quivera Coalition, which advocates for the conservation of biodiversity, soil and a management that strengthens the resilience of Western working landscapes. The study provided concrete information about the way in which PJ woodlands recover from tree mortality, immediately aiding the management of millions of hectares public land in the American Southwest. The project also produced a rich data source for refining PJ community models used to forecast ecological change in this nationally significant natural resource.

The project actively supported the improvement of science education in the K-16 community. A professional development training day was held for middle school teachers in the San Marcos (Texas) Unified School District, which informed participants about the methods and purpose of field experiments and the use of instrumentation to document changes in ecosystem function in response to climate trends. This was part of a broader effort to improve upon the oversimplified characterization of ‘the scientific method’ in the classroom that is the current standard. This included a novel graphical resource to convey how science uses diverse approaches in scientific investigation. This resource is now used regularly at Texas State University by biology and science education majors and was also submitted to the Texas Board of Education for possible in inclusion of the next version of the Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills standards to be adopted for K-12 education. Three postdoctoral associates, five graduate students, including a biology education major, and eight undergraduate students participated in the project, including seven women and four members of historically underrepresented ethnicities.
